headline: LiveLiveAlbanese leads Labor to Australia election win20 minutes ago20 minutes ago New PM already talking about world affairsNew PM already talking about world affairs47 minutes ago Meet Australia's next PMMeet Australia's next PM1 hour ago What went wrong for Scott Morrison?What went wrong for Scott Morrison?Live Albanese leads Labor to Australia election win  20 minutes ago
article:
Labor will form the next government after the Liberal-National coalition has failed to win enough seats But it is still not clear whether it will be a majority leadership or in coalition with independents and other parties Anthony Albanese will be the country's new prime minister overseeing the first Labor government in almost a decade Incumbent PM Scott Morrison has conceded defeat and congratulated Mr Albanese on his win Independents have also done well in the election so far, amid public dissatisfaction with the two major parties The rising cost of living and climate change have dominated this election as two key issues for voters It's nearly 3am in Sydney, where a few hours ago Australia's new PM Anthony Albanese gave a victory speech to thousands of cheering supporters. "I want to bring Australia together. I want to seek our common purpose and promote unity, and not fear or division,"  said the 59-year-old veteran politician who has led Labor back to power after nearly a decade. Here's a recap of the day's biggest takeaways:  This live page was brought to you by Rebecca Seales, Yvette Tan, Tessa Wong, Zubaidah Abdul Jalil and Aparna Alluri in Singapore, Jay Savage, Tiffanie Turnbull, Isabelle Rodd and Frances Mao in Sydney, Kirstan Ross in Melbourne, Zoe Kean in Hobart, and Tiffany Wertheimer in London. Thank you for joining us! As the day comes to an end, here's a look at some of the millions of Australians who cast their ballots today to elect a new government. Voters pose with their pooch outside a polling station in Melbourne A man votes at Bondi Beach, Sydney, wearing a pair of Speedos - what Australians affectionately call "budgie smugglers" Two year-old Lexi enjoys a "democracy sausage" - a staunch Australian tradition - after her parents voted in Dickson, Brisbane Brisbane voters wait in the rain to cast their ballots Peter Power enjoys a sausage sizzle after voting in Bellevue Hill, Sydney, with his dogs Lily and Dancer in tow Simon AtkinsonBBC News The first couple of days in a new job are often pretty cruisy right? Get set up on your email, find out where the stationery is kept, maybe discover what to do if there's a fire. But Anthony Albanese has got a more intense start. He will need to be sworn in as Prime Minister pretty quickly - perhaps as soon as Sunday. Because on Monday he will fly to Tokyo for the Quad leader's meeting with US President Joe Biden, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. France's outgoing Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian has said Scott Morrison's defeat at the polls on Saturday "suits me fine". There has been a political rift between the two countries since Australia scrapped a $37bn (Â£27bn) submarine deal with France last year, and instead made a new pact with the US and UK - so-called Aukus.  The move enraged French President Emmanuel Macron,who famously accused Mr Morrison of lying to him. "The prime minister's defeat suits me fine," Mr Le Drian was quoted by AFP as saying. "I hope we can resume frank and constructive dialogue with Australia in the future." Shaimaa KhalilAustralia correspondent Less than half an hour after becoming Australiaâs
prime minister-elect, Anthony Albanese faced his first major challenge - being "doorstepped" by the BBC. For a man so new to the job of running Australia,
he was surprisingly quick to talk about international policy, saying he was a
huge supporter of theAukus defence alliancebetween Australia, the UK and the
US. Mr Albanese also said that he wanted to follow in
the UKâs footsteps in being a climate action leader. Anthony Albanese with his beloved dog Toto Anthony Albanese is set to become Australia's next prime minister after leading the Labor Party to its first election victory in almost a decade. One of the country's longest-serving politicians, he promised voters "safe change" as he worked to kick out the conservative Liberal-National coalition which has been in power since 2013. Where ousted Prime Minister Scott Morrison is a self-described "bulldozer", Mr Albanese vows to be a "builder". After the pandemic, which saw Australian states cut off from each other and cities splintered by strict lockdowns, fostering unity is a top priority for the new leader. So who is Albo? Mr Albanese has earned a reputation as a defender of Australia's free healthcare system, an advocate for the LGBT community, a republican, and a passionate rugby league fan. The 59-year-old - nicknamed Albo - was raised in social housing by a single mother on a disability pension. He has often cited his upbringing as the foundation for his progressive beliefs. Read more here. Going into the election, all signs indicated incumbent PM Scott Morrison was in trouble. His tenure has been dominated by disasters and the pandemic, but also by his governmentâs many scandals. There was the ill-timed holiday to Hawaii as bushfires raged across Australia and the way his government treated women and handled sexual harassment claims. His character has also come under fire, from members of his own party and even the French President who accused him of lying. Last election he was dubbed a "miracle-worker" for pulling off an unexpected victory. So how did things go so wrong for ScoMo?Read more here. Simon AtkinsonBBC News, Sydney Every sentence Anthony Albanese delivered at Labor HQ was met with rapturous applause. Whether it was a commitment to the Uluru Statement from the Heart, making Australia the leader in renewable energy as part of a major shift in climate policy, or protecting the minimum wages of young workers to make sure they  kept up with inflation - with his call for optimism, not fear, Anthony Albanese outlined a different vision for Australia from the one projected by Scott Morrison. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has taken to Twitter to congratulate new Australian prime minister Anthony Albanese. "I look forward to working with you as we reap the rewards of our comprehensive Free Trade Agreement, the AUKUS partnership and the unmatched closeness between the British and Australian people," he wrote. More from Anthony Albanese's speech. The incoming PM preached a message of unity and hope, saying he wanted to "bring Australians together". "I want to seek our common purpose and promote unity and optimism, not fear and division. It is a show of strength to collaborate and work with people, not weakness." He also urged Australians to seize opportunities "to shape change, rather than be shaped by it", and said that together the country could "end the climate wars", become a renewable energy "superpower", as well as strengthen the economy, healthcare, and childcare. He also promised to establish a national anti-corruption commission, and reaffirmed his commitment to womens and Indigenous people's rights. He ended his speech thanking his party colleagues, campaign team, family, and finally his mum who is "beaming down on us". "I hope there are families in public housing watching this tonight. Because I want every parent to be able to tell their child no matter where you live or where you come from, in Australia the doors of opportunity are open to us all." Peter Dutton has scraped through in his Queensland seat of Dickson, paving the way for him to become the next Liberal Party leader after Scott Morrison's resignation. If he does put his hand up, it'll be Mr Dutton's second tilt at the top job. He unsuccessfully challenged then-Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull in 2018 after a dispute over energy policy. But it was Scott Morrison who ultimately won the party room support to replace Mr Turnbull. Mr Dutton - from the party's right faction - has been a controversial figure, and there are questions over whether he'll be able to win back support that the party lost in more progressive, metropolitan seats. Incoming Prime Minister Albanese said that PM Scott Morrison had in an earlier phone call "very graciously wished me well". "I thanked him for that and I wish him well. And I thank him for the service that he has given to our country as Prime Minister." Albanese went on to refer to his own humble beginnings as the "son of a single mum who was a disability pensioner, who grew up in public housing". "I hope that my journey in life inspires Australians to reach for the stars. I want Australia to continue to be acountry that no matter where you live, who you worship, who you love or what your last name is, that places no restrictions on your journey in life." At this point Albanese was drowned out by repeated cheering and chants of his name, to which he jokingly responded: "I know at the beginning of the campaign they said people didn't know me but I reckon they've got [the name by now].... Can we have a bit of order? I intend to run an orderly government and it starts here, so behave." Anthony Albanese, Australia's next prime minister, has just arrived at Labor's party headquarters to thunderous applause and cheers. He began his speech thanking Australians "for this extraordinary honour". "Tonight the Australian people have voted for change. I am humbled by this victory and I'm honoured to be given the opportunity to serve as the 31st Prime Minister of Australia. "My Labor team will work every day to bring Australians together. And I will lead a government worthy of the people of Australia. A government as courageous and hard working and caring as the Australian people are themselves." Australia's Treasurer and Liberal party member Josh Frydenberg has acknowledged it will be difficult to hold onto his Kooyong seat in Melbourne, as independent "teal" candidate Monique Ryan looks set to win. Kooyong has long been a Liberal seat, and this will mark a shock loss to a complete political newcomer. Frydenberg will also become one of the highest-ranking cabinet ministers to ever be voted out. "While it's mathematically possible that we win in Kooyong, it's definitely difficult," Frydenberg told supporters in a televised speech. His mood was markedly different earlier today when he posed for pictures with voters. Allow Twitter content? This article contains content provided by Twitter. The first Indigenous person to be elected to the House of Representatives and the first to serve as a minister has lost his seat. Ken Wyatt's seat of Hasluck has fallen to Labor as the Liberal Party suffer a massive swing against them in the state of Western Australia. Mr Wyatt - who has Noongar, Yamatji and Wongi heritage - was elected in 2010, and became the Assistant Minister for Health in 2015. He's held a number of portfolios since then, and in 2019 become the first Aboriginal person to be the Minister for Indigenous Affairs. Liberal colleague Senator Simon Birmingham said his defeat is a huge loss for the parliament. "While there are many colleagues I would grieve for tonight, it is important that we note the historic contribution that Ken Wyatt made to the parliament, as an Indigenous Australian, to serve at the highest levels of office," he said. "We pay tribute to him tonight."  Ken Wyatt was elected in 2010 Anthony Albanese will be Australia's next PM, but Scott Morrison's Liberal-National coalition appears to be in the lead on first-preference votes (see the chart below). Why is that? It's because Australia uses a preferential voting system - each ballot is numbered by voters from their most to least preferred. Candidates with the fewest votes are eliminated, but votes for them are still counted - theyâre re-distributed to the next preference listed on each ballot. The process is repeated until only two candidates are left, and the person with the majority is declared the winner. So under preferential voting, many of the Greens votes, for instance, are likely to move to Labor - as those voters are likely to have preferenced Labor above the Liberals. Nationally, networks are projecting that just over half the first-preference vote will go to Labor. Morrison took to the stage amid chants of "Scomo, Scomo" More on Morrison's concession speech - he said he was quitting as the leader of the Liberals, following their unsuccessful outing at the polls. Morrison, who led the country through bushfires and a pandemic, also gave thanks for "the miracle of the Australian people". "What Australians have endured over these past few years has shown a tremendous depth of character and resilience and strength," he said. "It has been the Australian people under the strong support of a strong government that's enabled all of us to come through to where we are today, and that's something that all Australians can give thanks for as 
we move forward.â He added that his party was handing over a country that was "in a stronger position... than we inherited it when we came to government those years ago under Tony Abbott". âWe leave government having secured our borders many years ago. And we leave government 

having restored our nation's defences.â A huge roar - the biggest of the night - erupted as Morrison ended his speech saying he "looks ahead to victory" in the next election, reports the BBC's Phil Mercer who was at the scene. Morrison was mobbed by television crews as he left the stage. Scott Morrison has just arrived at his Liberal party's headquarters and has conceded defeat to Labor's Anthony Albanese. He congratulated Albanese on his election success, and adds: "This has been a time of great upheaval." "It is important for our nation to heal" from disruption, he adds. The BBC's Phil Mercer who is at the scene says that a crowd of several hundred people, including former PM John Howard, had stayed behind to listen to Mr Morrison's speech. But the mood is not funereal, with free-flowing beer and wine keeping spirits up. It's hugs and cheers all round for Labor supporters this evening, as the party is set to form the country's new government. This is the first time Labor has come to power in almost a decade. Supporters were crossing their fingers for a win... ...then began to cheer as the results started coming in... ...and broke out in chants for "Albo" as networks called a Labor win. Labor's Sally Sitou was half-way through her victory speech when her supporters realised the party had won - and they broke out in cheers. Labor is still four seats short of the 76-mark for a majorty government, but that could change in the coming hours. Allow Twitter content? This article contains content provided by Twitter.
